> The situation I've seen is where a JS/AJAXy application uses the
> '#fragment' to affect the rendering or behavior of the page. For
> example, I've seen it used analogously to a client-side query-string:
>
> http://example.com/app#redirectTo=/help
>
> Javascript in such a page might load different URIs, construct different
> outlinks, or do an immediate redirect to a different URI depending on
> the '#fragment'. Theoretically (but not yet), Heritrix could find those
> links if it preserved the '#fragment'. (It also might need to
> re-extract, though not necessarily re-fetch, that same URI when it is
> encountered with a different '#fragment' later.)
>

Exactly. That's what I was talking about. Actually, I am even building
a 100% Ajax site myself right now that heavily relies on the hash to
store data. Without it, navigation is impossible :) (of course, you
need JS to use the site).

If you don't want to store the #fragment in the URI part in the WARC,
where would/could that go?

Jean-Noel
